EN

The provided article text features interviews from the FMLS:25 summit rather than the news headline suggested. Jonathan Fine interviews Dor Eligula of BridgeWise regarding the integration of AI in investment research, identifying growth opportunities in Asian markets, and how retail investors can safely utilize AI. Additionally, the text includes an interview with Brendan Callan, CEO of TRADU, who won a debate arguing against the current Prop Trading model, criticizing its reliance on fees, loose risk management, and lack of clarity for retail clients.

Key Points

  • BridgeWise discusses the rollout of AI in investment research and growth in Asian markets.
  • Brendan Callan of TRADU critiques the current Prop Trading model for fee dependency and risk issues.
  • The interviews cover the balance between automation and human judgment in financial services.

Article

We start with Dor‚Äôs reaction to the Summit and then move to broker growth and the quick wins brokers often overlook. Dor gives real examples of how automation and human judgment meet at Bridgewise ‚Äî including moments when analysts corrected AI output, and times when AI prevented an error. We close with a practical question: how retail investors can actually use AI without falling into common traps. Executive Interview | Brendan Callan | CEO, TRADU | FMLS:25 Executive Interview | Brendan Callan | CEO, TRADU | FMLS:25 Executive Interview | Brendan Callan | CEO, TRADU | FMLS:25 Executive Interview | Brendan Callan | CEO, TRADU | FMLS:25 Executive Interview | Brendan Callan | CEO, TRADU | FMLS:25 Executive Interview | Brendan Callan | CEO, TRADU | FMLS:25 Brendan Callan joined us fresh off the Summit‚Äôs most anticipated debate: ‚ÄúIs Prop Trading Good for the Industry?‚Äù Brendan argued against the motion ‚Äî and the audience voted him the winner. In this interview, Brendan explains the reasoning behind his position. He walks through the message he believes many firms avoid: that the current prop trading model is too dependent on fees, too loose on risk, and too confusing for retail audiences. We discuss why he thinks the model grew fast, why it may run into walls, and what he believes is needed for a cleaner, more responsible version of prop trading. This is Brendan at his frankest ‚Äî sharp, grounded, and very clear about what changes are overdue.
